research_question: Q1: Do participants converge more on Impact (Y) than Implementability (X)?
methodology_with_citation: Compute per-statement SDx/SDy then compare paired SDs with a paired t-test for mean difference; lower SD implies stronger convergence. Sources: NIST on standard deviation and paired t-test (https://www.itl.nist.gov/div898/handbook/eda/section3/eda35b.htm, https://www.itl.nist.gov/div898/handbook/eda/section3/eda353.htm).

research_question: Q1: Do participants converge more on Impact (Y) than Implementability (X)?
methodology_with_citation: Compute per-statement SDx/SDy then compare paired SDs with a paired t-test for mean difference; lower SD implies stronger convergence. Sources: NIST on standard deviation and paired t-test (https://www.itl.nist.gov/div898/handbook/eda/section3/eda35b.htm, https://www.itl.nist.gov/div898/handbook/eda/section3/eda353.htm).

research_question: Q2: Are there “consensus zones” (grid regions) where placements concentrate?
methodology_with_citation: Aggregate placements into 7×7 grid cells and compute counts/percentages (heatmap-style density). Sources: heat map overview and proportions (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heat_map, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proportion_(statistics)).

research_question: Q3: Which seed statements show the highest agreement in placement?
methodology_with_citation: Compute exact-cell agreement and within-1-cell agreement as proportions per statement; rank by agreement. Sources: proportion statistics and categorical agreement summaries (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proportion_(statistics)).

research_question: Q4: Which seed statements show the greatest disagreement in placement?
methodology_with_citation: Compute per-statement centroid and mean Euclidean distance to centroid as controversy score. Sources: centroid and Euclidean distance (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centroid, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euclidean_distance).

research_question: Q5: For which statements is disagreement driven more by X vs Y?
methodology_with_citation: Compare SDx vs SDy per statement and flag when SDx ≫ SDy or SDy ≫ SDx. Sources: standard deviation (https://www.itl.nist.gov/div898/handbook/eda/section3/eda35b.htm).

research_question: Q6: Which practices are seen as high impact but hard to implement?
resultat: Set an escalation SLA for unresolved blockers: mean_x=2.43, mean_y=6.50 (n=14).
methodology_with_citation: Compute statement centroids (mean x/y) and apply quadrant rule x≤3 and y≥5. Sources: arithmetic mean (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arithmetic_mean).

research_question: Q7: Which practices are seen as easy to implement but low impact?
resultat: No statements met mean_x≥5 and mean_y≤3 criteria.
methodology_with_citation: Compute statement centroids (mean x/y) and apply quadrant rule x≥5 and y≤3. Sources: arithmetic mean (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arithmetic_mean).

research_question: Q8: Do different seed themes map to different grid regions?
resultat: Coordinate across teams and unblock: mean_x=3.18, mean_y=6.04 (sd_x=1.33, sd_y=1.79).
methodology_with_citation: Group statements by theme, then compute centroid (mean) and dispersion (SD). Sources: arithmetic mean and standard deviation (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arithmetic_mean, https://www.itl.nist.gov/div898/handbook/eda/section3/eda35b.htm).

research_question: Q10: How extreme/consistent are participants in their placements?
methodology_with_citation: Compute extremity rate as proportion of placements on grid edges and within-person SD of x/y. Sources: proportions and standard deviation (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proportion_(statistics), https://www.itl.nist.gov/div898/handbook/eda/section3/eda35b.htm).

research_question: Q11: Can participants be grouped into placement profiles based on shared seeds?
methodology_with_citation: Standardize participant vectors on shared seeds, select k via gap statistic and silhouette, then run k-means. Sources: k-means, gap statistic, silhouette (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K-means_clustering, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gap_statistic, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silhouette_(clustering)).

research_question: Q12: Which statements best separate participant clusters?
resultat: Not analyzed: Q11 excluded, so no cluster-separating statement output.
methodology_with_citation: Would compute between-cluster centroid gaps per statement if clusters existed (conceptually based on centroid distance). Sources: centroid and Euclidean distance (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centroid, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euclidean_distance).

research_question: Q13: Do placements differ by function (e.g., Marketing vs Product)?
methodology_with_citation: Compare X and Y distributions across functions using Kruskal-Wallis H test. Source: NIST on Kruskal-Wallis (https://www.itl.nist.gov/div898/handbook/eda/section3/eda35f.htm).

research_question: Q13: Do placements differ by function (e.g., Marketing vs Product)?
methodology_with_citation: Compare X and Y distributions across functions using Kruskal-Wallis H test. Source: NIST on Kruskal-Wallis (https://www.itl.nist.gov/div898/handbook/eda/section3/eda35f.htm).

research_question: Q13: Do placements differ by function (e.g., Marketing vs Product)?
resultat: Top centroid distance: Design vs Operations = 1.26 (Δx -1.19, Δy -0.42).
methodology_with_citation: Compute function centroids and rank by Euclidean distance. Sources: centroid and Euclidean distance (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centroid, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euclidean_distance).

research_question: Q14: Do placements differ by country/region?

research_question: Q14: Do placements differ by country/region?

research_question: Q15: Do placements differ by role level?

research_question: Q16: Does tenure predict perceived implementability/impact?
resultat: Tenure vs mean implementability: r = -0.14, p = 0.617.
methodology_with_citation: Compute Pearson correlation between tenure and mean x/y per participant. Source: NIST on correlation (https://www.itl.nist.gov/div898/handbook/eda/section3/eda35a.htm).

research_question: Q16: Does tenure predict perceived implementability/impact?
resultat: Tenure vs mean impact: r = 0.42, p = 0.107.
methodology_with_citation: Compute Pearson correlation between tenure and mean x/y per participant. Source: NIST on correlation (https://www.itl.nist.gov/div898/handbook/eda/section3/eda35a.htm).

research_question: Q16: Does tenure predict perceived implementability/impact?
resultat: Tenure vs extremity rate: r = 0.53, p = 0.033.
methodology_with_citation: Compute Pearson correlation between tenure and extremity rate per participant. Source: NIST on correlation (https://www.itl.nist.gov/div898/handbook/eda/section3/eda35a.htm).

research_question: Q17: Does hybrid % relate to placement patterns?

research_question: Q17: Does hybrid % relate to placement patterns?
resultat: Hybrid% vs mean impact: r = 0.60, p = 0.013.

research_question: Q17: Does hybrid % relate to placement patterns?

research_question: Q17: Does hybrid % relate to placement patterns?
resultat: Share three user stories that embody the goal: r = -0.97, p = 0.000 (implementability).

research_question: Q17: Does hybrid % relate to placement patterns?
resultat: Protect 2 hours/week for learning tied to the goal: r = 0.93, p = 0.000 (implementability).
